overview: UK visa sponsorship information for employers - sponsorship licences, requirements, certificates and visa tiers
title: UK visa sponsorship for employers

table.body:
Before you can apply for a sponsorship licence you need to know which type of licence you need.

There are different categories (or tiers) of sponsorship for employees:

* Tier 2 - skilled workers with a job offer
* Tier 5 - temporary workers

##Tier 2 - skilled workers with a job offer

Tier 2 sponsorship can be:
 
- general - for people coming to work in the UK with a skilled job offer which is National Qualifications Framework (NQF) level 6 or above. 
- intra-company transfer - for multinational companies sending their employees to the UK for jobs of NQF level 6 or above
- sportsperson - for elite sportspeople and coaches that will be based in the UK
- minister of religion - for people coming to work for a recognised religious organisation (for up to 3 years)

###Scotland

In Scotland, a skilled job offer has to be Scottish Credit and Qualifications Framework (SCQF) level 9 or above for both general work and intra-company transfers.

##Tier 5 - temporary workers

Tier 5 sponsorship can be:

- creative and sporting - to work as a sportsperson (up to 12 months), entertainer or artist (up to 24 months)
- charity worker - includes both paid and voluntary workers (up to 12 months)
- religious worker - for those doing preaching, pastoral and non-pastoral work (24 months)
- government authorised exchange - for those coming to the UK through an approved scheme (24 months)
- international agreement - for those coming to the UK for a job that is covered under international law, eg. employees of overseas governments

*[NQF]:  National Qualifications Framework
*[SCQF]: Scottish Credit and Qualifications Framework
table.title: Before you can sponsor an employee

table.body:
When you apply for a sponsorship licence, you apply for an annual amount of [unrestricted certificates of sponsorship.](http://www.ukba.homeoffice.gov.uk/business-sponsors/points/sponsoringmigrants/applyforlicence/annual-allocation/ "Unrestricted certificates of sponsorship"){:rel="external"}  You can also apply for [restricted certificates of sponsorship](http://www.ukba.homeoffice.gov.uk/business-sponsors/points/sponsoringmigrants/employingmigrants/apply-for-restricted-cos/ "restricted certificates of sponsorship"){:rel="external"} during the year through the [Sponsorship Management System.](http://www.ukba.homeoffice.gov.uk/business-sponsors/points/sponsoringmigrants/sms/whatissms/ "Sponsorship Management System"){:rel="external"}

You can get a licence if:

* you aren’t in breach of immigration control
* you can meet your sponsorship duties
* you are an organisation or recognised religion operating legally in the UK 

You may have to provide documents to prove your organisation is genuine and operating legally in the UK. 'Appendix A' has more information about which documents are suitable.

$D
[Download 'Appendix A - list of documents' (PDF, 303KB)](http://www.ukba.homeoffice.gov.uk/sitecontent/documents/employersandsponsors/pbsguidance/guidancefrom31mar09/appendix-a.pdf?view=Binary "Download 'Appendix A - list of documents' (PDF, 303KB)"){:rel="external"}
$D

You must [apply online](https://www.points.homeoffice.gov.uk/gui-sponsor-jsf/SponsorHome.faces "UK Border Agency"){:rel="external"} for a sponsorship licence.

##Where to send your documents and fees

You must send all supporting documents and [fees](http://www.ukba.homeoffice.gov.uk/business-sponsors/points/sponsoringmigrants/costs/costofalicence "Application fees"){:rel="external"} to the UK Border Agency (UKBA).

$A
Sponsor casework operations  
Sponsor applications team  
UK Border Agency  
PO Box 3468  
Sheffield  
S3 8WA  
$A

All supporting documents must be original or certified copies, eg signed by a solicitor or notary. Any documents not given in English or Welsh need to be translated with the translator’s details included. Your application will be rejected if all the documents aren’t sent in.

If you're successful the UKBA will put you on its list of registered sponsors and give you a set number of certificates of sponsorship to sponsor employees.  

You can contact the UKBA to find out the status of your application:

$C
**UKBA Sponsorship and Employer’s helpline**  
0300 123 4699  
<sponsorlicensing@ukba.gsi.gov.uk> 
$C

##Sponsorship ratings

If you're successful you're given an A or B licence rating.

An **A rating** means there isn't any evidence of abuse of the immigration system and you have support in place to meet your sponsorship duties.

A **B rating** means there isn't enough support in place meet your duties or there is previous evidence of abuse of the immigration system. The UKBA will help you improve your rating.


*[UKBA]: UK Border Agency
table.title: Apply for a sponsorship licence

table.body:
You must:

* follow the [code of practice](http://www.ukba.homeoffice.gov.uk/business-sponsors/points/sponsoringmigrants/employingmigrants/codesofpractice/ "Code of Practice"){:rel="external"} for sponsoring skilled workers
* if needed complete a [resident labour market test](http://www.ukba.homeoffice.gov.uk/business-sponsors/points/sponsoringmigrants/employingmigrants/residentlabourmarkettest/ "Resident Labour Market Test"){:rel="external"} for Tier 2 general workers 
* keep records of your employee
* report changes in your employee's working status to the UK Border Agency (UKBA), eg they stop showing up for work, they quit
* follow immigration laws

If you don’t follow your duties your licence can be downgraded (from A to B status), suspended or taken away.

You must give your employee a certificate of sponsorship so they can apply for a visa or extension of their stay.  You are given the certificate of sponsorship once you are licensed with UKBA.

*[UKBA]: UK Border Agency
table.title: What you must do as a sponsor

table.body:
The certificate is a virtual document with a unique reference number that lets employees apply for a visa or extension of their stay.  

You must pay for each certificate of sponsorship you give but don’t get a refund if your employee does not use it.

###Changing sponsored employees' employment

If an employee wants to change their employment (with the same or a new employer) they must reapply under the points based system.

The only exception is if they work with the same sponsor and the new job will be the same [standard occupational classification](http://www.ons.gov.uk/ons/guide-method/classifications/archived-standard-classifications/standard-occupational-classification-2000/dissemination-media-and-availability/index.html "standard occupational classfication"){:rel="external"} as their original certificate of sponsorship.
